Articles

Articles

Three steps to make your plot

This vignette reviews the steps needed to realize your summary plot with correct error bars.

Why use difference-adjusted confidence intervals?

This vignette explains the difference between a regular confidence interval and a difference-adjusted confidence interval.

Why use correlation-adjusted confidence intervals?

This vignette explains the difference between a regular confidence interval and a correlation-adjusted confidence interval.

Plotting Cohen's d with ``superb``

This vignette shows how to illustrate Cohen’s d with superb.

Plotting proportions with ``superb``

This vignette shows how to plot proportions using superb.

Plotting frequencies using ``superb``

This vignette shows how to plot frequencies along with confidence intervals.

Plotting Reference Intervals with ``superb``

This vignette shows how to illustrate reference intervals using superb.

The making-of the figures in the article

This vignette provides all the steps needed to make the figures from the article.

Customizing `superb` plots

This vignette shows how to fully customize your plot produced by superb.

Adding labels to ``superb`` plots

This vignette shows how to add labels to plots generated from superb.

Unequal variances, Welch test, Tryon adjustment, and ``superb``

This vignette examines the assessment of mean differences when variances are unequal, its relation with Welch test and how Tryon adjustments can help.

(advanced) Alternate ways to decorrelate repeated measures from transformations

This vignette examines the various techniques that performs within-subject decorrelation from transfomations of the raw scores. They can be shown to share many elements.

(advanced) Local decorrelation for time series

This vignette provides an overview of the local decorrelation technique from time series with vanishing amount of correlations.

(advanced) Non-factorial within-subject designs in ``superb``

This vignette shows how to handle non-factorial designs using superb.

Using a custom statistic with its error bar within ``superb``

In superb, it is possible to summarize your data set with any descriptive statistics. The most common descriptive statistics are built-in superbPlot, but if you wish to use a different descriptive statistics, it can easily be added to superbPlot. This vignette explains how to add a custom descriptive statistic and how to add its precision interval to superbPlot.

Using a custom plot layout within ``superb``

superbPlot can generate either line plots, barcharts, or point plots. However, additional layout can be programmed. In this vignette, we show how to add custom layouts in superbPlot. As an example, we show how to implement additional layouts.

``superb`` and SPSS

This vignette shows how to use superb with SPSS files or within SPSS.

Generating ready-to-analyze datasets with GRD

This vignette covers the basics of GRD, a tool to generate random datasets. These data are ready to be analyzed. They can be generated from any population distribution, and exhibit any effect.

Developed by Denis Cousineau.
